subject: Re: [junit] Unit 4.0 release candidate 2 Test ordering

messageBody:
On 1/20/06, Robert Lucente <rlucente@...> wrote:
>
> "I know that some will argue that I should
> use more mocks to reduce dependancies"
>
> It depends on the situation. Sometimes creating a mock involves a lot of
> effort.
>
> It seems like we have 3 situations ?
>
> 1) Run all the tests in any order
>
> 2) Run these x tests in this y order and stop as soon as you hit the first
> failure.
>
> 3) Tests that combine 1) and 2).
>
> I am a newbie and haven't read/studied the doco carefully. So, I don't
> know
> how easy it is to do 2).
>
> "value in the concept of dependency"
>
> Definitely !


Good to see this recognized.

A typical example is Web tests: what's the point of running a hundred tests
exercising servlets if the Web server failed to start? It also helps for
the diagnostic: instead of telling the user "101 tests failed", you can
tell them "1 test failed, 100 tests were skipped".

TestNG lets you define dependencies on methods (which is fragile) and on
groups, which is much more flexible since adding test methods to groups
doesn't force you to adjust your dependencies.


On 1/20/06, Mark Levison <mlevison@...> wrote:On 1/20/06, Robert
Lucente <rlucente@...> wrote:
>
> 2) Run these x tests in this y order and stop as soon as you hit the first
> failure.


All I want with Dependancy is run test x before all the tests that depend on
it. If test x passes then run the other tests in any order. If test x fails
then don't run those tests. I believe this is called partial ordering.


On 1/20/06, Mark Levison <mlevison@...> wrote:
>
>
> All I want with Dependancy is run test x before all the tests that depend
> on
> it. If test x passes then run the other tests in any order. If test x
> fails
> then don't run those tests. I believe this is called partial ordering.


Exactly.

Dependencies typically represent a small portion of your tests: most of
them can usually be run in any order.
